post.title: A Quentin Tarantino Spotify Playlist
post.summary: “I said I want a Spotify Playlist!” Just a quick post today to try something new: A Spotify Playlist. The more observant readers amongst you will have noticed that I put a Spotify link at the bottom of each post I write, to allow those who have a Spotify account to easily play the record I am writing about. I have no clue as to whether anyone actually uses the link. But – like me – even if its not very useful to most people, at the very least it looks pretty. Or so I keep telling myself, anyway. So given my last article was about the new Tarantino film – Django Unchained – I thought I would put together a Tarantino playlist. If you have a Spotify account you can subscribe to the playlist and it will add itself to your song collection. Probably. Don’t ask me how this stuff works – I have trouble getting an electric toothbrush to work. I have taken my two favourite songs from each film, and if you wanted a quick fix of Tarantino soundtrack, then you could do a lot worse than to download this: Record #146: A Quentin Tarantino Spotify Soundtrack

post.title: paper 53 logo
post.summary: So, I've had an iTunes gift card for over a year and a half, but I never purchase music because I use Spotify and I never watch movies, well, because, well, I'm a Netflix junkie, so I decided to "splurge" on Paper 53. It's so adorable, and I know, from a designer standpoint, it's sort of awful since it costs extra money to get a color mixer and you can't change the thickness of your tools, but the calligraphy pen is so enticing, I had to get the whole set. I ended staying up until 2 AM making an "Idea" journal for logo ideas for the graphic design "company" I work for!

post.title: Nokia estrena su servicio Music+ con descargas ilimitadas de música
post.summary: Nokia ha dado a conocer su servicio de música Music+ que le permite a los usuarios acceder a la música que quieran con descargas ilimitadas a un pago mensual bastante razonable. Music+ comenzará a funcionar dentro de unas semanas pero la compañía ha señalado que el precio variaría de región en región, sin embargo dio a conocer que sería de unos $5.37 dólares que haciendo comparaciones estaría más o menos al mismo precio que la versión Premium de Spotify. Entre lo que ofrecerá Music+ está la opción de cambiar de pistas las veces que quieras, descargas ilimitadas de música para usarlas offline, audio en una mejor calidad, letras de las canciones en pantalla y posibilidad de usar la aplicación web en una computadora. De momento no se sabe los países en los que se estrenará Music+ pero estaremos al pendiente para informarles todos los detalles. Vía: Nokia

post.title: My Momma Heart: Splashed by that big, deep, wave of emotion.
post.summary:
“You are never alone, you can always come back home.” -Jason Mraz, 93 Million Miles “Just know, that wherever you go, no you are never alone, you will always get back home.” – Jason Mraz After a night of serene snowfall, I woke up to a chilly Saturday morn. Should I go to the gym or stay nestled under my comfy spread? After a few steps, my arthritis called, “Go to the gym. You always feel better.” So, off I went. Driving slow, of course, because the roads were quite icy. En route to the YMCA, I saw a dad and his three children pulling sleds….that’s all it took. Be still my momma heart.
The big, deep wave of maternal emotion splashed hard. Tears welled and my heart skipped a beat. Those were the days, I thought. I wanted to roll down the window and scream, “Enjoy ‘em while their young,” but I was desperately afraid he would call the cops on a crazy redhead heckling from her car. I got to the Y and it was closed. Oh my. I should have known. On my way home, I turned on the radio. A song played that took my breath away. It seemed the perfect theme for my morning drive, already full of nostalgia, pristine views, and thoughts of a child so far away. I pulled over and Spotify’d the song, bought it and listened to it over and over again. Most of the time I do pretty well with the fact that my dear Candace Rose is on other side of the world, but that snowy morn…that song on the radio…those children laughing and carrying their sleds…opened the floodgates. Oh, I want to make hot chocolate and sit with her, right now. Why, oh, why is she a million miles away from me? So, as the wave overwhelmed me, I gasped for air and made my way to the shore of Knowing. Knowing she was right in the center of God’s powerful plan for her life. Knowing without a doubt she was happy, safe, and wildly living her dream of wanderlust. Knowing she was unfolding like the rose for which she is named. Knowing….that wherever she goes, she is never alone, and that she can always get back home. Right in the center of her Father’s will. Her joy brings me joy. Maybe your momma heart hurts right now. I understand. Let this beautiful ballad wash over your pain. Jason says it well, “The absence of the light is a necessary part.” We raise strong, independent children so they can go change the world. I just didn’t know it would hurt so much. But then, thanks to modern technology, just minutes after I returned home, she called. God is so good to this momma. He knows, doesn’t he? I sure do pray that God will provide your momma heart with whatever it needs…right now. The beautiful thing is that we can always go Home, too, can’t we? Home to our Father’s heart. WE ARE NEVER ALONE.

post.title: Vinicius Cantuaria – Pe Na Estrada
post.summary: Listen to Vinicius Cantuaria - Pe na estrada (3,13 min) on spotify. Pe na estrada can be found on the album Indio de apartamento which were released 2011, track nr: 10About Vinicius CantuariaVinicius Cantuária was born in Manaus, Amazonas, Brazil, living there until he was seven, when his family moved to Rio. As singer, songwriter, guitarist and percussionist, his career connects several zones of brazilian music. And though his music is known for its decidedly twenty-first century feel, Cantuária's band might best be described as 'post-electronica acoustic' - a band that includes jazz bassist Paul Socolow, Michael Leonhart (the young Steely Dan trumpeter) and a rotating crew of Brazilian percussionists Nanny Assis, Mauro Refosco and legendary drummer Paulo Braga. Their repertoire typically includes songs by Antônio Carlos Jobim and Gilberto Gil, as well as Cantuária's own fund of songs. last.fm Pictures of Vinicius CantuariaShow more imagesMore: Vinicius Cantuaria Vinicius Cantuária's officiella homepage

post.title: Music Curriculum: El Ten Eleven
post.summary:
In today’s day and age, the possibilities you can create with music are virtually endless. That being said, there’s a lot of shit in our generation’s music culture. But every so often, we stumble across a band or a musician that can change our lives.
So I’m super into post-rock, and I’m always looking for different styles of it. Today I stumbled across this band, El Ten Eleven on spotify. What has impressed me the most about this band is the fact that it’s a duo. One on a guitar-bass double neck combo, and the other on percussion. It’s some really beautiful music so you should definitely check it out.

post.title: Nokia launches Music+ subscription service, sadly it requires Windows Phone
post.summary: Music means different things to different people. Some listen to music to elicit an emotionally response, others just want something on in the background while they’re doing menial labor. Whichever group you’re a part of isn’t really relevant though, everyone here has to admit that technology has changed the way music is consumed. People used to buy albums, then they bought digital singles, and now it’s all about the streaming services. Google doesn’t have one, Apple doesn’t have one, but that’s OK since there are companies out there like Spotify. For those who don’t know how Spotify works, it’s like Netflix. You pay a monthly fee and you get to listen to whatever it is you want. If you stop paying money, then no more music for you. But there’s another company that doesn’t get a lot of attention from the press regarding their music service, and that’s Nokia. “Nokia Music” is easy to describe if you’ve heard of Last.FM or Pandora. You pick an artist or musical genre, and then the service picks songs it thinks you might like. If there’s a song you don’t like, you can skip it, but there are only so many times you can skip per hour. This service is free, but today Nokia is introducing a paid version called Music+. What do you get for 4 USD (4 EUR abroad) per month? Higher quality audio, unlimited skips, unlimited offline playlists, and there’s even a new web app. Why are we talking about Music+ here? Because we want Google to copy it. Google knows so much about us, where we are, who we talk to, what we search for, so why can’t it predict what music we’ll like? Countless services talk about their libraries of 20+ million songs, but who cares if you don’t know which tracks are worth your time? Come on, Google, make us proud. Related Posts Sony launches Music Unlimited streaming service in Japan, offers access to over 10 million songs HTC and Beats Audio set to acquire music subscription service Mog? post.title: Olive One
post.summary:
Olive, an audiophile device company, has set the next step on the path to convenient access to music via online streaming. The Company’s newest device is called the Olive One, it is a “disk-shaped audio player with a built-in HD amplifier, single volume dial and 7-inch touchscreen to choose your music” (SOURCE)
IMAGE: Indiegogo The company has basically taken the popularity and ease of streaming music players you might find on a computer or iPhone (such as Spotify) and created a device with high-end audio components to please music fans and audiophiles. With hard-drive storage, you can also store your own music library. It also includes iOS, Android and Windows 8 apps which allows your handset to connect and work as a remote control to the device. The device is priced at $400 on Indigogo, and has been made possible via public funding and investments. I love the look of the Olive One, it’s stylish and offers portability, connectivity, high quality sound and a world of music at your fingertips.

post.title: Laneway Festival Singapore 2013
post.summary:
Wow! As I said, my first time going to a music festival. Although I almost fainted due to the hot weather (it was over 30C with no shades, no clouds, bright hot sun shining on us since morning until the sunset…was almost unbearable! I think it was one of the major issues since the water isn’t free… Things got blurry for me once, so I had to sit down and put my head down to not faint. After that I just tried to take it easy and drink lots of water and covering my shoulders with my cardigan to not get sun burned, oh and apply sunblock over and over again haha..still I managed to burn my arm…!
This is what it looked like last night when I got home…PAIN!! Quickly applied aloe vera gel before going to bed and been re applying regularly so it’s much better today =) The seats we had were good too, close enough to the stage, in between both of them so that we could sit. Never had to move. Took off my shoes and just enjoyed the company and stood up dancing whenever there was a song that called for it haha We stayed until around midnight..so 12-13 hours there
I had a blast. Of course, it wasn’t perfect, but I had a great time =) I understand why people like music festivals like this. The feeling is…free..=) Like having a picnic with a lot of people at the same time, but with awesome live music playing and no one who thinks you’re weird if you decide to stand up and shout and dance..Later on, think it was when Real Estate was playing, we laid down and listened to the music. It was really nice. The night sky was clear so there were plenty of stars. Never done that before..=) Watching Of Monsters And Men was without a doubt the highlight for me (no surprise there hehe). They’re great live and really knows how to entertain and involve the audience. They were super popular as well, everyone moved closer to the stage for their performance and they even did one more song due to their popularity, which was highly appreciated since the running sheet for the bands are fixed and very tight. I really liked the other bands as well! Not all of them were my taste, but majority had a few songs I have on my Spotify now Oh, there were so many pretty people there as well..like wow!! =) Anyway, making a video so I’ll post it when it’s done =)

post.title: The Coda
post.summary: To escape the cold that makes me feel old this week I took another trip up to Trumpet Mountain.I walked into the main hall and heard Clifford Brown practicing in a room inside.I stood outside and listened.The stuff he was playing was way,way past running down chord changes. "Brownie's been hanging out with Don Cherry and Don Ayler" I was shocked to hear these words come from none other than Gil Evans standing in front of me.Gil said he was on Trumpet mountain to talk to Miles about a new symphonic work but that nobody had seen him. "I'm glad I ran into you Matt Lavelle.I have some thoughts about you and that lady Alto Clarinet.You have been friends now a long time,isn't that your third Alto? Look,.when you sold the Bass I knew you weren't bullshitting but your still acting like your just friends.It's time for intimacy my friend.I'll tell you what you all ready know.The key is to get your articulation tight.You need to personalize and finalize that haunting thing you get from the horn.It's dark.Miles loves it and told me he was going to use that color someday." "Do me a favor and tell my friends Bones Malone,Howard Johnson,Bruce Ditmas,and of course my son Miles I said hello.I know you see them at that music store you work at.Sorry to hear that Music Row is done." Suddenly Clifford himself emerged from the practice room smiling. "Hey man!" Clifford and I shook hands right away,it was like we had known each other since forever even though we just met.He was still holding the horn off course. "Matt Lavelle.Your almost out the oven.I'm glad you came by.Here's how to put the cherry on top of your sundae.Articulation." There was that word again.Shit,I've heard guys whisper that around me before.Maybe I was drunk. "I'll tell you one thing about Wallace Roney and Wynton Marsalis,they can articulate there ass off! That was my deal,what made me have such a personal thing.That's the final step for you.As usual,just don't look to Miles,Wallace has better articulation then him anyway.Check out how Clark Terry works out of clarinet books..that's a way for you to unify your deal and become yourself.I never got down in Eb..you like it? You do have a lot to say,just try and say it better.You know how you are with those typos on your blog.Don Cherry gave me a copy of your "In Heart Only" the other day.Nice stuff man." "Now you have to go back and move Sam Ash from Music Row.You know Kenny Dorham worked at Manny's right?" ..... Indeed.What a trip to run into those guys.Before they left I listened to a record Brownie and Gil made together,and no it's not on Spotify son.I took there advice to heart.As they both said I now had to deal with moving the entire Sam Ash store on 48th to w34th st.Rockefeller Rent was to damn high so this long chapter of NYC culture gotta go.West 48th between 6th and 7th once had up to 30 different musical operations going down according to Paul Ash.I've had worse survival systems,way worse,so I'm in the trenches while we move.Moving stores is not new to me.I moved TOWER uptown once,and even Sam Ash across the street when our original brass building was condemned for structure damage.The Ash is after all where I get most of my material.I was on the fence about bringing my jam session back but I got a pep talk from a trumpet player who was truly touched by my thing to get people on common ground to celebrate the sound of life. Back on the home front I'm seeing that when it comes to music and NYC I'm one of those people who just cant let it go no matter how void of culture the city becomes.I'm not here to entertain in the great playground for the rich,I'm here to talk to the world even if it does take them 30 years to hear me.I just don't want the world to pass me by,a fate worse then death.NYC never stops asking you if you really have something to say.I've taken to studying and enlisting some Internet marketing since most of the world spends half of their lives online just like I am right now.If I wasn't here in NY I wouldn't be writing this blog.I would be writing some kind of free Jazz Science Fiction novels.Maybe I still will in my Art Studio in Tenor Town over in Cloudland.No matter what happens I just don't want to go down like Peter Parker and get forced out.Spidey's death still has me tossing and turning every night. My people here in the heights know me better than I know myself. After Snoopy the Chiwawa came running down the hallway to say hello to me for the 5th time today my man Rogelio asked me in Spanish: Rogelio:"Mateo..still with that FLU? I knew you weren't immune like you said." Mateo:"Just one day man,I declared war on the Gripe and won.Mad juice.My crazy dreams were worse than ever" Rogelio:"I told Mirella.When I heard that horn coming out of your room again I knew you were better" Coda: Never better,since ever day you wake is another chance to see the sun. It's just when you think you've lost,you've won. . . . . For Snoopy,with special thanks to Clifford,Gil,and Gretchen Parlato for her lyrics that helped me find a good Coda.Thanks as well to Esperanza Spalding who's music played while I wrote.Wish I could write like her.Been writing a lot as of late,might have to take a Hiatus in Clarinet City.Peace.
post.blogName: That Fat Eb feels Mahogany to me.Matt Lavelle

post.title: Samsung-Geräte in der Melodie den Mittelpunkt rücken zur Unterstützung von Nicht-Samsung-Politik zu haben, Lochfraß mit Google und Amazon ausgerichtet
post.summary:
Samsung-Geräte in der Melodie den Mittelpunkt rücken zur Unterstützung von Nicht-Samsung-Politik zu haben, Lochfraß mit Google und Amazon ausgerichtet Artikel von http://www.Laptopakkushop.At/: Samsung hat erhebliche Geräte zur Unterstützung seiner Cloud-basierten Melodie Fokus Angebot. In der Sphäre der neben Aufrollen alter Hut über den eigenen Bereich der angeschlossenen Politik, ist die Absicht, in diesem Moment immer größer es neue weithin auf Hardware von anderen Herstellern unterstützt auch die Firma erzählt. Melody Fokus ist ein Cloud-basierten Dienst Kombination eines Benutzers eigenen Dateien mit Spotify-style-Streaming, Datenleitungen und Entdeckung Hautstruktur. Es ist zum größten Teil ein Konkurrent zu traditionellen Melodie Lebensmittel, online Datenleitungen, Streaming-Dienste und Cloud locker Dienstleistungen allem im Bereich des einzigen Paket. Es ist derzeit einsame auf dem Samsung Galaxy S III und Ton II, aber TJ Kang, SVP zur Unterstützung des Samsung Media Services zu haben gesagt, der anschließend ein verworrenes Netz in der heutigen Zeit mit dem Ziel, den Tisch zu bekommen größer die Verfügbarkeit geht Ferne genau der eigenen Hardware. Kang, die in der Sphäre des Cannes, Frankreich ist an der Seite der weitsichtigen Montag Midem Veranstaltung morgen unterhalten, dachte mit dem Ziel zu beginnen, ist die Tabelle zur Unterstützung der Melodie Fokus auf die eigenen Handys Samsung erreichen, Medizin , smart TVs und möglicherweise sogar andere Politikbereiche wie z. B. seine Android-powered verbunden Kühlschrank. Melody Schwerpunkt liegt gegenwärtig im Bereich der sechs Länder hatten aber seine geografische erreichen ist fit, in 2013 verlängert werden. Er bestätigte jedoch, mit dem Ziel, Kunden zu besuchen, um eigene Hardware aus einer Vielzahl von Herstellern und mit dem Ziel der Ausweitung Melodie Fokus auf diese Politik unterstützen würde das Leben leichter Unterstützung von ihnen zu bringen. Melody Fokus bereits auf solche als Download auf Google werden musste auf den Teil des (mit Unterstützung des Galaxy S III und Ton II), so erweitert es um nicht-Samsung-Politik (bei kleinsten Betrag auf Android) sollte vorhanden sein stressfrei während das Unternehmen beschließt, bringen mit dem Ziel der Bewegung. Was ist aufmerksamkeitsstarke an dieser Stelle mit dem Ziel, dies würde Melodie Fokus auf Schritt vom gerade eine gute Unterstützung der Samsung-Kunden Mehrwert und bauen es wie eine ausdrückliche Konkurrent Amazon, Google und andere Firmen, die Cross-Plattform Melodie Dienstleistungen mit dem Ziel, bieten Kombinationen von Downloads, Streaming-und Cloud-Schließfächer. Der Richtung, nicht mit dem Ziel, nicht unbedingt mit dem Ziel, den Verbrauchern bevorzugt, um zur Unterstützung der es ernst meinen. Im Vergleich bietet Sony die Melodie unbegrenzte Streaming-Dienst auf eigene Hardware und auf Desktop-Computern, Apple iOS und Nicht-Sony-Maschine-Politik, und doch nicht zu besuchen, mit dem Ziel, im Bereich der genannten hören gleichen Atemzug wie Spotify und Rdio. Die aktuelle Version der Melodie Schwerpunkt ist die Folge von Samsung die Übernahme von Silicon Valley ansässige mSpot im Bereich der möglicherweise auf Zeit tragen. Kang sagt mit dem Ziel der Integration von mSpot Hautstruktur dauerte genau 20 Tage von dem Deal wird angekündigt, und das war die elementare Übernahme durch fit Firma Samsung (was produziert das Unternehmen der Unterhaltungselektronik-Linien), da es PC-Hersteller AST in der Sphäre zu suchen haben 1997. So ist das Unternehmen spürbar schwerer zum Thema Melodie Fokus, die eine solide Angebot im Bereich der Vergleich zu seinen Konkurrenten ist. Kang sagt uns, mit dem Ziel, den Zeitpunkt zur Unterstützung einer breiteren Einführung von Melodie Schwerpunkt zur Unterstützung der Samsung Hardware hängt die Sicherung Gebiet-spezifische Angebote mit Melodie Etiketten und befreien Zeitplan zur Unterstützung des Unternehmens die Möglichkeit Kernstück der Politik im Jahr 2013. Er kann auch lassen jemanden haben Abfuhr Zeitrahmen zur Unterstützung der Verfügbarkeiten anderer Hardwarehersteller, sondern einfach gedacht, mit dem Ziel, eine solche Verfügbarkeit war das Ziel des Unternehmens. Sie bevorzugt vorhanden sein können TJ Kang Geschwätz und die Lüge der weitsichtigen Montag Midem beobachten, Livestream im an dieser Stelle auf der später ein verworrenes Netz von morgen in der Europäischen Tages. Die Veranstaltung beginnt mit der Seite 11.00 Uhr MEZ. Tags: Samsung, Melodie Fokus, google, amazon Article from: Battery skill Dell FU571

post.title: Bands to Watch - WALK THE MOON
post.summary: This weekend has been baller as hell. It started with a great show on Friday night. I went to see Cincinnati rockers Walk the Moon on Friday Night at Music Hall of Williamsburg with my buddy Rachel. This guys took down the effin' house. Seriously the energy that they brought to Music Hall of Williamsburg was unbelievable. They played through their entire premiere album, I Want! I Want! and went on to introduce us to some of their new tunes off their Tightrope EP. Highlights for me were definitely when they played my new fave song (of the moment) Tightrope (video below) and when they closed out the night with Anna Sun before coming back for a more than generous encore. I would have loved to hear that tantalizing new cover of Burning Down the House that they released on Spotify, but no worries because me and Rachel just sang it the whole way home. We decided it was our duty to give Brooklyn that performance in lieu of Friday's headliners. I have to say, we put that red wine to good use. Walk the Moon's sound is so cool and eclectic. So fun without being pretentious. I adore seeing artists who love being on stage (this is a follow-up to my blog from earlier this week). These guys were having so much fun, and Nicholas Petricca (who I've lovingly been referring to as "The Mayor of Bonertown" because dayum he's adorbs) sounds just as good on stage as he does in the studio. Very satisfying . . . VERY SATISFYING! And now I feel like such a dope because I didn't realize that they were from Cincy! Turns out I'd even met some of them back at the Fringe in 2010. Here is my favorite moment of realization: me: Did you realize you're friends with the singer of Walk the Moon on FB? 10:55 AM God he is so fooiiinnneeeee 11:09 AM Karim: ! He took a clown workshop I taught at fringe. So yeah, that happened, apparently.

post.title: Kulturbloggen möter Kate Boy
post.summary:
Kate Boy består av Hampus Nordgren Hemlin, Oskar Sikow Engström, Markus Dextegen och den australienska sångerskan Kate Akhurst. Efter att Northern Lights spridit sig som en löpeld och hajpats på bloggar världen över ger nu IAmSound (som även arbetar med akter som Charli XCX och MS MR) ut deras debut-EP med samma titel. Vi på Kulturbloggen passade på att ställa några frågor till denna svensk-australienska kvartett som redan hyllats av såväl Pitchfork com The Guardian. Kan ni berätta lite om hur ni träffades och när ni bildade Kate Boy? - Kate kom till Stockholm för att skriva låtar och vi träffades allihopa under hennes näst sista dag i staden. Vi bestämde oss för att få ut och dricka eftersom vi ville ha setts en gång innan studiosessionen dagen därpå och det slutade med att vi gick direkt till studion den natten. Det var spontant, vi skrev Northern Lights den där första natten. Sedan spenderade vi de efterföljande två dagarna i studion och visste allesammans att vi var tvungna att fortsätta samarbetet på något sätt. Hur kom låtarna på EP:n till? Har ni några bestämda roller i låtskrivandeprocessen? - Vi har inga bestämda roller eftersom vi alla gillar att vara inblandade i varje steg. Trots våra olika musikaliska bakgrunder har vi många likheter när det kommer till vilka instrument vi spelar. Det är snarare ”tänkandet” som kan skilja sig. Vi kan alla ha olika idéer om hur vi ska approacha en låt eller i vilken riktning vi ska ta den, men när det kommer till att skriva texter, melodier och produktion är vi alla delaktiga i praktiskt taget alla moment. Hur skulle ni själva beskriva er musik? Vad inspirerar er till att skriva låtar och vilka är era influenser? - Vi är väldigt inspirerade av de elektroniska ljuden från 70- och 80-talet och hur de brukade blanda organiska och elektroniska, nästintill robotaktiga, ingredienser. Den elektroniska musikens pionjärer, såsom Kraftwerk, Peter Gabriel och Jean-Michel Jarre, är viktiga komponenter i Kate Boys inspirationslåda. Men mycket inspiration kommer även utanför musiken, film är till exempel något vi alla delar en stor passion för. Det är något med konceptet som kanske inspirerar oss mer än specifika ljud och ord. Den där känslan när du träder in i en värld och vill stanna där – den känslan vill vi åstadkomma med vår musik. Att du kan känna igen och höra att det är oss på samma sätt som du kan säga direkt om det är David Lynch eller Stanley Kubrick som gjort en film.
Producerar ni låtarna själva? Hur bestämmer ni er för vilka ljud ni ska använda? - Ja, vi producerar låtarna själva. Efter att ha spenderat så mycket tid tillsammans i studion har det slutat med att vi hittat ett eget sätt att tänka gällande vilka ljud vi ska använda. Lite som kockar som jobbar i samma kök, vi delar med oss av våra erfarenheter och smaker för att skapa nya recept tillsammans. Slutligen hittade vi ett särskilt recept som ”smakade” som oss. Vilka planer har ni för den närmsta framtiden? Blir det konserter eller en fullängdare snart? - Vi kommer definitivt att turnera och släppa ett album. Just nu arbetar vi med att skriva vårt album samtidigt som vi håller på att planera vilka ställen vi ska besöka. För den närmsta framtiden så har vi videos och några till singlar som släpps snart. Hur gick det till när ni blev signade av IAmSound? Var det fler bolag som hörde av sig och i så fall, varför valde ni just IAmSound? - När Northern Lights började sprida sig kontaktades vi av bolag. Vi respekterar och älskar musiken på IAmSound – samt vad de har gjort med sina artister – vilket gjorde beslutet att ge ut vår EP genom dem enkelt. Vad tycker ni om den elektroniska musiken för tillfället? - Det är inspirerande att se hur elektronisk musik har kunnat utveckla en väg in i nästan alla genrer. Den stora utmaningen är kanske att ge någonting tillbaka till den elektroniska musiken, genom att använda fler riktiga instrument. Det finns så många producenter där ute och datorerna är bombarderade med nya instrument och sätt att utveckla och producera musik. Det är nästan så att musikscenen laddar upp inför en stor explosion av framtida hybrid-genrer. Det är verkligen en tid präglad av att alla har en chans att producera musik.
Finns det några akter ni ser upp till eller som ni skulle vilja samarbeta med? - Det finns så många artister som vi skulle vilja arbeta med, vi älskar co-labs. Men vi skulle inte stanna vid musiker, vi skulle även vilja samarbete med personer som gör annat än att skriva låtar – designers, illustratörer, fotografer eller bara slumpmässiga personer som tänker utanför ramarna – vi vill samarbeta med dem allihop. Blev ni överraskade när er musik började sprida sig på nätet? Hur betydelsefulla har nätet och bloggar varit för er? - När vi först delade med oss av videon till Northern Lights var det bara till våra vänner. Tanken var att vi skulle marknadsföra den senare, men innan vi visste det tog den fart på egen hand. Det är så inspirerande att se hur enkelt du kan nå ut till lyssnare från hela världen. EP:n innehåller även ett par remixer, kan ni berätta lite om dem? - Vi är stora fans av Taken by Trees, så när vi hörde hennes version älskade vi att det var en så ny version av låten. Och Superhumanoids-remixen var så ambient, långsam och kraftfull vilket blev bra kontrast till vår version. Vi älskar båda och visste direkt att de skulle komma med på EP:n. — And here’s an English transcription for all you international readers: Can you tell us a bit about how you met and when you formed the Kate Boy? - Kate came to Stockholm to write some songs and we all met up on her 2nd last day. We went out for drinks since we wanted to meet before our session the next day, and ended up going straight to the studio that night. It was instantaneous, we wrote Northern Lights that first night. We spent the next 2 days in the studio and knew we’d all have to continue our collaboration someway, somehow. How did the songs on the EP come about? Do you have any set roles in the songwriting process? - We don’t really have any set roles since we all like to be part of every step. Despite our different musical backgrounds, when it comes to which instruments we play we are very alike. It’s rather the ”thinking” that can differ. We can each hear different ways to approach our songs and which way we want to direct them in, but as to writing the lyrics, the melody and producing the track we are all hands-on on almost every level. How would you describe your music? What inspires you to write songs and who are your influences? - We are very inspired by the electronic sounds from the 70′s and 80′s and how they would mix organic and electronic, almost robotic ingredients. Electronic music pioneers like Kraftwerk, Peter Gabriel and Jean-Michel Jarre are very important components of the KATE BOY inspiration box. Also a lot of inspiration comes from things other than music. Film is something we all share a big passion for. There’s something about the concept that inspires us more maybe than specific sounds or words. That feeling when you enter a world and you want to stay there. We want the same feeling with our music. To be able to hear or know that it’s us, just in the same way you instantly know that it’s a David Lynch or Stanley Kubrick movie. Do you produce the songs on your own? How do you come up with which sounds to use? - Yes we produce our own songs. After spending so much time together in the studio, we’ve ended up sculpting a common way of thinking when it comes to which sounds to use. It’s like chefs working in the same kitchen, exchanging experiences and tastes to create new recipes together. Eventually we found a particular recipe that ”tasted” like us, if that makes any sense. What are your plans for the near future? Will there be concerts or a full-length album soon? - We will definitely be touring and releasing an album. We are working on both right now, planning which places to visit and also writing our album. As for the near future, we’ve got videos and more single releases coming soon. Can you tell us about how you got signed to IAmSound? Were there other labels trying to sign you as well (if so, why did you choose IAmSound)? - When Northern Lights started spreading we got approached from labels. We respect and love the music on IAmSound and what they had done with their artists, which made the decision to release our EP through them an easy one. What do you think of the current electronic music? - It´s inspiring to see how electronic music has evolved its way into almost every genre and seems to continue reaching out. Maybe the big challenge is to give something back to electronic music, by using more real instruments. There’s so many producers out there, and the computers are bombarded with new instruments and ways to evolve and produce music. It´s almost as if the music scene is charging up for the big boom of new hybrid genres of the future. It´s really the era of where everyone who wants has a shot to produce music. Are there any acts you look up to or would like to collaborate with? - There are so many artists who we want to work with, we love co-labs. But we wouldn’t stop at musicians, we’d also love to collaborate with people who do things other than making the song – designers, illustrators, photographers and just random out of the box thinking people – we’d like to collaborate with them all. Were you surprised when your music started to spread on the internet? How important has internet and blogs been to you? - When we first put out the Northern Lights video we originally only shared it with our friends, the plan was to promote it later on but it took off on its own before we knew it. It’s so inspiring to see how easily you can reach listeners from all over the world. On the EP there’s also a couple of remixes, how did those come about? - We’re big fans of Taken by Trees, so when we heard her version, we loved that it was such a fresh take on the song. And the Superhumanoids remix was so ambient, slow and powerful which made a great contrast to our version. We loved them both on first listen and knew they’d be on the EP. — Här kan du lyssna på EP:n via Spotify:

post.title: Music Monday – The Acoustic Sessions: Volume One by Casting Crowns
post.summary:
Need something new to listen to this week? Casting Crowns just released their new album of acoustic music, and it is fabulous. I say this with all due deference to Mark Hall, but I feel that this is the album they couldn’t do at the beginning of their recording career. His vocals have matured over the years and are very good on this record. Check it out. You’ll be glad you did. If you use Spotify, listen below.
Filed under: Music

post.title: Just like the Arnie. I'm back. Plus, Stephon LaMar
post.summary:
Yes, after nearly a year, I'm back. And this time I'm back for good. Well hopefully. At the moment I'm finding that I have lots of free time being awarded to me. As you can maybe tell seen as I'm posting this at 2am on a Monday morning. Anyway I'll tell for why I've decided to make a return... So tonight I was replying to a friend who had tweeted a very attractive picture of herself (@isobel_end for those wondering, top lass). And I mentioned a two syllable damn, and she didn't know what I meant. You know, the ones that go: DAYYUMMM. If you don't then just google it. So that's what I did to look for an example to show my friend. I didn't find one but I came across this guy: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DcJFdCmN98s But that's not the guy who made me blog again. No, no, no it's much more exciting. Anyway so I scroll down afterwards and see that three guys have done a cover. Now normally I'm a bit sceptical about these YouTube covers done by people who think they can sing. Well turns out these guys can actually sing: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VfbQ4gww7aI
I clicked on the guys link at the end of the video and I was impressed. He sings a good range of music. Here are some examples: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=trbsLgaZhW0&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThVmjGqgk9Y&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fe9TUQSJFTE&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxyX9rjIlb8&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
I just realised most of them are covers, but he does do his own stuff.
I love his voice it's really got that quality to it. There's a demand for this kind of singing I think. It's the stripped back, acoustic-ness of the songs that I like. Anyway, I really like this guy so I wanted to share him with the world. I really want him to do well because he should do. Check out his YouTube channel, Twitter, Facebook and all that. I'll be listening to him on my Spotify account and I'll share that on Twitter too. He also has an EP out. Check it. https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/lamoureux-ep/id474780707
Peace.
@WJMonde

post.title: MEOW! Presents: The Best Films of 2012!
post.summary: January 27th, 2013 MEOW! Well, this is about a month late. Let's get right to it. Here are the best films of 2012 in the order of their release dates! 21 Jump Street (March 16th, 2012)--I've got two words for you: exploding. chickens. If you were able to crack at least a smile at those words, then you are in for one of the funniest comedies to be made in quite some time. Bernie (April 27th, 2012)--What an impressive gem by Richard Linklater, with a truly underappreciated performance by Jack Black, also known as the Dragon Warrior. It's on Netflix instant right now, so if you have that, give it a go. ParaNorman (August 17th, 2012)--From the clever usage of horror-movie stereotypes as Norman's team, to the WONDERFUL messages of acceptance and tolerance for children of all ages, this film is among the best of the stop-motion animation genre. Hopefully this film finds more of an audience soon. The Perks of Being a Wallflower (September 21st, 2012)--This film has it all and more in spades: bittersweet cinematography, a pitch-perfect ensemble led by Logan Lerman, and an eye-opening direction and script written by Stephen Chbosky, who also wrote the 1999 novel of the same title. If you ever come across this film in your life, watch it, and I swear, you will feel infinite. Magic. Looper (September 28th, 2012)--With a brilliant imagination by Rian Johnson, and two outstanding performances from Joseph Gordon-Levitt (his best film to date) and Bruce Willis (YIPPIE KAY YAY!), this is a fantastic film of the sci-fi genre. How this film got snubbed for a Best Original Screenplay nomination is beyond me. Cloud Atlas (October 26th, 2012)--One of the most underappreciated films of all-time, let alone decade, this is an amazing experiment of ambitious, imaginative filmmaking. You know you love a film so much when you listen to most of the score's compositions on Spotify. Skyfall (November 9th, 2012)--Coming from someone who has only seen Quantum of Solace out of the 22 Bond films created at the time (crucify me now if you must), I was extremely impressed with Bond #23. Under the excellent direction of Sam Mendes, containing moments that will make you proud to be a moviegoer, Skyfall is a terrific tribute to a 50-year-old film icon. Rise of the Guardians (November 23rd, 2012)--I will never walk in as a skeptic to a Dreamworks film ever again. This is a roller coaster ride of breathtaking visual imagination, while also being a poignant tribute to the child in all of us. And choose caution: if you are a 90's kid, and/or are able to let the moments of your own childhood flow right into your memory, you could very well tear up during the end credits. Bring a friend so that he/she can hug you. Your welcome. Silver Linings Playbook (November 23rd, 2012)--Who knew that a film about two people with mental illnesses falling in love with each other can be fresh, wonderful, and genuinely romantic? David O. Russell scores another touchdown by writing and directing an involving (albeit predictable) romantic comedy, with by a fantastic ensemble led by Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence. And now we cue my love letter to the best film of 2012.... Wreck-It Ralph (November 2nd, 2012)--Even though the rest of the films on this list have given me hope for the future of cinema (no pun intended when it comes to LOOPER), no other film in 2012 had made me happier to be who I am today than Wreck-It Ralph. Exploding with brilliance and creativity in nearly every frame, with an unapologetic heart of happiness and melancholy, I now understand how people felt back in 1939 when they saw The Wizard of Oz for the first time (ironically, there's a reference to that film, and it will blind-side you with its genius). It's as good as The Hunchback of Notre Dame when it comes to being the best thing Disney has ever produced, and it's up there with some of the best (animated) films that I've ever seen. I can't think of anything bad to say about it. It's truly a perfect film. Honorable Mentions: Chronicle, Jeff, Who Lives at Home, The Hunger Games, The Pirates: Band of Misfits, Moonrise Kingdom, Prometheus, Ted, Hope Springs Until next time, MEOW!

post.title: Canción de la NBA en Cuatro y Canal Plus Deportes
post.summary:
Dormir es de cobardes, o al menos eso piensan los aficionados al basket que cada madrugada de viernes se citan frente a la tele para seguir la emisión de los partidos de la mejor liga de baloncesto del mundo, la NBA, que emite Cuatro en abierto y Canal+ en modalidad de televisión de pago, y que cuenta con el habitual equipo de narradores de la casa (David Carnicero, Iñaki Cano, etc,...) y los siempre acertados comentarios de Antoni Damiel (un must a seguir en twitter), José Ajero y Nikola Lončar.
Pues bien, hay un tema musical que suena durante las retransmisiones de este "curso baloncestístico" 2012-2013 que como era de esperar no ha pasado desapercibido para vosotros, al menos a tenor de las múltiples peticiones que hacéis para conocer cuál es el nombre de la canción.
La canción, que comienza con el sonido del repicar de unas campanas, casi a modo de aviso del espectáculo de baloncesto que se nos avecina, sirve como banda sonora del vídeo de presentación de los dos equipos que disputan el partido de esa noche.
Apuntad bien el título, porque se trata del contundente "Run Boy Run" de Woodkid, el proyecto musical del multidisciplinar artista francés Yoann Lemoine, del que ya hemos hablado en alguna que otra ocasión en este mismo blog. Tanto nos gusta este "Run Boy Run", que la hemos incluído en nuestra lista de spotify de las mejores canciones de 2012. El videoclip dirigido por él mismo, tampoco tiene desperdicio.
"Run Boy Run" de Woodkid Descargar en: iTunes Escuchar en: Spotify

post.title: HELT ÆRLIG:
post.summary:
Jeg orker ikke mer.
Jeg er drittlei alt, alle og meg selv. Jeg er sliten, leg og har mest lyst til å bare gi faen i alt, bare gi opp, ikke gidde mer. Folk er falske, slemme og ubeskrivelig irriterende, dessuten bruker de deg før du bare blir lagt bort som gårdagens VG, som om du ikke var verdt noenting. Det er ingen som faktisk bryr seg, jeg har ingen andre enn meg selv jeg kan stole på og jeg begynner å få litt for mye på tallerkenen. Jeg er ensom. Jeg hater det å sove alene, være alene og føle at jeg ikke er viktig for noen. At ingen er ekstra glad i meg, akkurat sånn som jeg er. Verden er en kald og jævlig plass for tiden, fyllt med mye dritt. Jeg gråter av ingenting, har ikke energi til å trene, og tilbringer all ledig tid i senga med øynene plantet i veggen, taket eller lukket. Har havnet i en veldig ond sirkel, og det påvirker humøret når jeg er sammen med andre. Skolen er blitt stress, jobb er tiltak, og hadde man ikke vært avhengig av penger for å komme seg gjennom livet ville jeg helst bare ligget i senga og råtnet bort. Bare forsvunnet. Dessuten er jeg sint. Sint fordi noen av de rundt meg føler at det er greit å spøke med det at jeg har en dårlig dag. Sint fordi ingen helt forstår hvordan jeg har det, hva jeg føler og hvor vondt det gjør i hver celle i hele kroppen når jeg må male på meg et tryne og feste et falskt smil før jeg går ut døra. Sint fordi håret mitt aldri vil ligge sånn jeg vil, at lovehandles igjen er på plass etter måneder uten trening og fordi jeg ikke har disiplin til å dra den feite ribberæva mi på tredemølla. Sint fordi bare jeg kan endre tankegangen min og sykdommen, men ikke har kapasitet til å klare det. Jeg er sinna. Jeg er så sinna at den neste som prøver å fortelle meg at jeg syter for mye og er for negativ kan vente seg en high five i trynet med en stol. Det ER faktisk ikke frivillig. Jeg vet ikke hva jeg skal gjøre med tingene sånn de er nå. Jeg kan ikke slutte på skolen, det skjer ikke. Jeg kan ikke slutte på jobb, for penger må jeg jo ha. Jeg har gitt opp å gå til psykologen, for etter 6 mnd ser jeg enda ikke vitsen med å sløse penger på en som ikke får meg til å kunne bli bedre. Jeg glemte å ta pillene mine nesten en hel måned, og vet ikke om jeg har lyst til å begynne på de igjen siden jeg like gjerne kunne vært zombie. Følelsesløs. Merkelig nok klarer jeg ikke sove om natten, uansett hvor sliten jeg er. Jeg tenker altfor mye, og i det siste har jeg hatt noen helt forferdelige mareritt hvor jeg våkner skrikende og søkkvåt av svette. Jeg sliter tilogmed å skille marerittet fra virkeligheten av og til, og da blir jeg redd, så gråter jeg. Det jeg kunne trengt mest da er en klem, at noen sa at alt er fint. Istedet blir jeg liggende våken, tenke og se gjennom tusenvis av bilder tagget med "depressed" og "alone" på weheartit mens jeg hører på deppelista på spotify mens jeg vet at dagen som kommer blir like jævlig som de dagene før. Jeg har holdt meg flytende lenge. Kanskje litt for lenge? Men nå har jeg møtt veggen igjen. Jeg har kræsjet. Jeg er et bilvrak og ingen svarer på 112.

post.title: Nokia intros Music+ subscription service with unlimited downloads, web listening
post.summary: Most of the bigger streaming music services have both a free tier for casual listeners and a paid level for truly committed music fans. Nokia doesn't want to be the exception to the rule. It's launching Nokia Music+, a paid version of its existing platform. Paying €4 per month ($4 in the US) gives perks that you'd normally expect from a more expensive alternative like Spotify or Slacker's premium tier: the upgrade ratchets up the audio quality, adds lyrics, allows unlimited skips in Mix Radio and enables as many downloads for offline play as the phone can hold. Aren't you suddenly glad that you picked up a 32GB Lumia 920? Not that you'll always need it to tune in -- Music+ adds web streaming for anything with a suitably capable browser. Nokia hasn't said just which countries beyond the US will get the more advanced service, but it should make a formal debut within the next few weeks. Filed under: Cellphones, Portable Audio/Video, Internet, Mobile, Nokia Comments Source: Conversations by Nokia Source: http://feeds.engadget.com/~r/weblogsinc/engadget/~3/WrqO_Mycdik/ drew peterson untouchable herman cain south carolina palmetto rob lowe sanctum the notebook duke basketball

post.title: Junior Review
post.summary: Greetings and welcome to my blog. My name is Lyna Luong and I am a visual artist at the Boston Arts Academy. I am currently a Junior at BAA and this post will be about my work this year. Starting off with my strongest skills, one of my strongest skills is to take time and work on a piece of work when I am motivated. I can do anything when I have the motivations. I am someone who needs something to push me when it comes to visual arts work. I do well when I go out and find things that are inspirational instead of receiving an idea and go and work on an art piece myself. This is not the same for other works. It’s just visual arts that I have to put more efforts in to find something inspirational to work off of. Another skill I have is that I tend to go super dark with whatever material I work with. Somehow, going dark makes me feel better than work lightly then go dark afterwards. It’s a skill because that is what I like and want to do. My art pieces reflects who I am, what I used to make the work, and how I use them. Nothing can stop me from doing what I want and how I want to do something because I have the ability and right to chose what I want to do and show off. If there is something that I want to improve, I would want to be better at finding inspirational ideas and the right motivations to create the content of my artworks. This is because I've been making art pieces that have other people’s ideas in it and I don’t want anyone’s help. However, if I don’t get the help, I wouldn't know where to go. I need to find better confidence in my art pieces because I don’t want anyone’s influences in my work. Another thing is that I am not a fan of critiques because I don’t like them and I plan to keep them out of my way no matter what. I’ll accept them, but I may or may not consider them. Maybe that is something else I need to get better at. It might benefit me, but then sometime I would have questions like, “If I take your ideas and critiques, would the work still be about me, or YOU?” Since sophomore year until now, I think there is a huge gap between the “sophomore me” and the “junior me”. Since the beginning of my junior year, I've been slowly moving away from being an art student to becoming an artist. I've been making progress, because the art pieces that I worked on during my junior year has my own ideas and own creativity in them. Instead of creating an art piece entirely off of the teacher’s ideas, I also put my ideas in that piece as well to make it my work. . The process that I take to be make art work is very long and hard. First of all, if I want to start an artwork, I have to make sure that I am finished with my other commitments because that way I can devote myself in my artwork. Secondly, after I give myself time, I have find something that would be inspiring and motivating to work. This step is important for me because if I don’t find something that would catch my interest, I may end up stopping in the middle of the process, and the art piece may also end up not finished. The third step of my process is to find a place where I can work, where it is quite, where no one can reach me or bother me, and a place where the atmosphere will make me work continuously. This is another important step because if I work in a place with other people, including family members and friends, it would be really annoying because I would not be able to focus on my work, and I’ll end up with nothing finished. Sometimes my room is the best working place because sometimes it would be quiet and no one could get in touch with me. When I say “no one” can get in touch with me, that means I would turn off my phone, get away where no one will know where I am (except my mother), and do my work. After finding “the place” to work, I have to settle into the place I choose to work at. This is when I use my iPod to go onto Pandora, a radio site, or Spotify and put on a station to play. Music helps a lot with the process because it enhances my mood to work sometimes. It’s rare, but sometimes listening to music will give me ideas of what to do. After finding music, I would go and get something that is easy to nibble on because snacks prevents hunger from taking over my mind when focusing on my work. After everything I need is around, I would start working. There are days that I get a lot of work done and some days I don’t. That’s mostly because it all depends on my mood, the atmosphere around me, inspirations, and motivations. During the Fall of my Junior year, I've been trying to work bigger in my visual arts work. For example, for my American Gothic inspired work, I thought I would end up working with a small base that everyone had to start off with, but when I was finished with my work I found out that I had worked with a bigger board than I had planned. Trying to work bigger is not important for me, but since teachers say working bigger is good, I would try to do my best to so and experiment with it. For some unexplained reason, I like to work with small things. For example, drawing small figures, building small crafts, and doing small projects. Working big has been the biggest risk I've done in visual arts and I learned that working big could result in bigger pride. I was proud of myself when looking at My Invincible Flower, the American Gothic inspired work, because it’s probably my biggest suitable accomplishment ever. For this semester, I've been in an art history class, and it was okay. I learned about arts in different time periods, in different styles, by different artists, and by different techniques. From art history, the only connections I've made in that class was when we were learning about the Baroque and the Romanticism time periods. This was because the Baroque had so many paintings with drama and movements, and when I was looking at them I felt something that can't be explained. I am very strict when picking an art piece to like and admire because I don’t judge based on the techniques, the values, or other things that the school is teaching the visual students. Instead, I pick art pieces that makes a good impression on me when I first look at it. To be honest, there’s hasn't been one piece of artwork that I've seen that I liked, or admired. During art history class, some of the works made a little impression on me even though it wasn't enough to the point where I liked it. I don’t know how to explain it, but the “The Raft of Medusa” by Gericault from the Romanticism period made me think of innocence people. The reason why I felt that way was because the story behind that painting is that there was a ship named Medusa, and on that ship were at least one-hundred people. Medusa was wrecked at one point and the people who were on the Medusa built a raft to survive on until someone saves them. When the raft was spotted, only fifteen people survived. The story was touching and that was pretty much the part that made a deep impression on me. It was like the Titanic. I guess for me, a fascinating art piece will need to have a touching story, a good first impression from the art work, and also the most important thing is that the artist of the work will have to fit my “ideal artist” because the artist’s impression on me is also important. Below are some of the art works I've worked on this Year. (2012-2013) PSY'S SCREAMING HORSE Art Gallery AMERICAN GOTHIC INSPIRED ANGEL MY INVINCIBLE FLOWER PAK BOM UNNI SARANGHAEYO AMERICAN GOTHIC BAROQUE STYLE AMERICAN GOTHIC by LYNA
